Is milk bad for you? Uncertainty, need *MOAR* studies because *correlation 
does not imply causation*. I can't confirm, even in *China study*.

biochemistry, diet and lifestyle in rural China* on >>
http://www.ctsu.ox.ac.uk/~china/monograph/<< for confirmation. You may also 
read *The China Study vs the China study* >>
http://www.proteinpower.com/drmike/cancer/the-china-study-vs-the-china-study/#more-4213<<, 
*A Closer Look at the China Study: Dairy and Disease*
>>

You follow raw till 4 youtubers? Like durianrider, happyhealthyvegan, 
simplyvegan, freelee, plantbasedathlete to name a few good ones. They show 
a lot of what they "ate today" videos. I personally don't cook anything 
fancy, I just smash fruit by itself, throw berries on my oatmeals, eat some 
flaxseed or hempseeds but no free oils, and I usually eat rice with beans 
and potatoes plain. Check out worldshealthiestfoods named website, they 
have a lot of fancy recipes, some are vegan. Or you could just google 
things like "healthy vegan low fat recipes". I personally eat anything 
that's high carb low fat plant foods, but my main staples are rice, oats, 
potatoes, broccoli, brussels sprouts, kale and for fruits I eat a lot of 
bananas, citrus fruits etc. because I live in Finland we don't have much 
fresh fruit here.

comments.text:
+Cillendor Edenion
You're welcome, the only reason some people fail on this diet is that they 
bring their past restrictive eating disorders to it. You shouldn't be 
expecting instant weight loss, your body might need time to heal from the 
metabolic damage of your past eating habits, so don't even think about your 
weight. Just get enough calorie dense high carbohydrate plant foods - and 
you'll be lean and healthy long term :)

comments.text:
Well, the scandinavian countries have a much stronger tradition of drinking 
milk. Most countries will use milk nearly exclusively for cereal, an 
ingredient in other food, or not at all, all alternatives where the taste 
of the milk is nearly irrelevant, and only its other qualities are 
important.
It's like olive oil. Most of the western world just uses it so food doesn't 
stick to the frying pan. In Italy they put it on their bread like we would 
use butter, and the olive oil down there is really friggin good compared to 
what we get up here.
Companies will do exactly as much as they can get away with.
In Norway and Sweden, crappy milk would lead to a riot.

I didn't include Denmark, because I think they exclusively drink beer there.

top_comment.text:
So, since I used to love milk, I did a ton of research on this topic. My 
conclusion is: milk is not good for you. Milk, and all other animal 
products, are for worst-case scenarios like a famine, but not for daily 
consumption. Milk does not have any nutrients we can't find in plants, and 
personally, I find it highly unnatural to drink the milk that was meant for 
another baby (and the baby cows, if they don't get slaughtered, get what 
then? some crappy substitute? GMO altered corn? yum..). Also, milk has tons 
of hormones, because it is meant to make a baby cow BIG and strong. Way 
bigger and stronger than humans could ever be. Lastly, milk makes the body 
acidic (which makes it easier for cancer to spread and is also bad for the 
heart) and is a combination of fat and sugar, which is bad for diabetics. 
Ok, enough said... just my opinion :D﻿
top_comment.author: mirjam.magdalena

comments.text:
+Wataheadable The notion that people led harsh lives at the brink of 
starvation when humans largely thrived in hunter-gatherer societies is a 
myth. In fact, things got tougher for us for a while when we transitioned 
from a nomadic hunter-gatherer lifestyle to an agricultural lifestyle.
comments.author: Dojan5

comments.text:
Plants aren't nearly as available as Milk is in the current economy. By 
that i mean plants do not have advertisements and promotions, Aswell as the 
appealing nature Milk has to people. Back 10,000 years ago, starvation 
wasn't a rare thing. 

Infact you'd be lucky to not be starving without being the top of the food 
chain, this is apparent in poorer nations where they eat spiders as protein 
for ageing teens, but then eat vegetables and Vegan food as a main dietary 
requirement. Mostly these are Asian Oriented nations.

Honestly i don't get why people care what others do. If i want to drink 
milk from another animal, i should be allowed to do it without harassment 
from someone who has to be extremely sceptical. Just so you know, if people 
were to base their dietary priorities to Crops and Such, the population of 
earth would have some serious epidemics, aside from the obvious issues with 
mass producing and farming crops (Toads, Seasons) we'd see for example a 
huge de-crease in sport intensity, Look at what Usain bolt, Michael Phelps 
and Ian Thorpe eat.

And aside from the fact that Seasons and Crop eating animals effect on the 
production, who would mass produce our "Back-up" resource of Animal food 
for the world, considering everyone "Should" be vegans. There would be no 
money in those industries.

Honestly nothing is as straight forward as it seems. You should let people 
choose their own path in life. (I am biased because a hippie knocked me out 
with a bat on a wharf for fishing, i nearly drowned) I have probably gotten 
some things wrong, but not everyone has the patients to care what you or 
other Vegans have to say, especially when we only live for a short time.

Although i do hate watching animals harmed.
comments.author: Wataheadable

comments.text:
+VeggiePandya "Fun" fact, the median lethal dose of water is 90 grams per 
kilogram of body mass. For an average human this is about 7.2 kilograms of 
water. This is 7.2 litres or a bit less than 2 gallons if you prefer.
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Median_lethal_dose

biggest milk-drinker imaginable. Once I stopped consuming dairy products my 
health improved overall. Most notably was that I didn't feel lethargic all 
the time, and my throat and sinus problems were drastically reduced.

Sure enough it might be unrelated, or might be because I was consuming way 
too much milk, either way I haven't regretted dropping dairy products from 
my diet at all.

comments.text:
+Passion And Fruit Get an education.  IGF-1 stands for insulinlike growth 
factor.  It's a water-soluble protein hormone that gets harmlessly digested 
before it has the chance to enter the bloodstream.  Cholesterol is an 
essential ingredient in animal cell membranes, including human cell 
membranes.  Only its overconsumption is dangerous.  Animal protein does not 
cause cancer in and of itself.  

Oh, and many fruits and vegetables contain auxins, which are plant growth 
hormones meant for a plant, not humans.  100% true.  Did you know, by the 
way, that fruits are plant ovaries?   Also 100% true.  So maybe you should 
think about if you want to keep on consuming plant ovary material that is 
meant for plant seeds, not humans. 

No matter what you consume, you are killing other organisms, damaging other 
organisms, or eating biochemicals that were "meant" for the organism, not 
for you.  Doesn't matter if it's milk, meat, fruit, nuts, whatever.  Your 
arguments - the standard-issue PETA/vegan arguments - deny the fact that we 
ALL live at the expense of other organisms, and are stupid.
comments.author: SRO 102078

comments.text:
Well, when someone resorts to the "waah, I don't like you and couldn't care 
less about you" line, I pretty much know you're out of legitimate 
arguments.  80%?  Where'd you get that figure?  I rather suspect you're 
pulling it from thin air.  Lactose doesn't "probably pose a danger to their 
organisms," you moron.  It's a disaccharide made from glucose and 
galactose, and whatever we don't digest, the bacteria in our GI tract do.  
That's the cause of gas.  Not a threat to health, or are you going to tell 
me that farting is fatal?   You're absolutely ridiculous.  My intention is 
to debunk your false claims so that other people don't end up as 
ill-informed as you.  Based on how you're begging to get out of this, I 
rather suspect I have.  Have a nice day!
comments.author: SRO 102078

comments.text:
+SRO 102078   *sigh* *back* *at* *you* I don't know to what you are 
replying, but it's clearly not to what I've written. Nowhere have I stated 
that only northern europeans have evolved this ability and are the only 
instance of lactose tolerance in humans, read again - " *certain 
populations* " - it could mean that it's peoples on islands in the Pacific, 
in Siberia, in Central Europe, Australia etc. They could've evolved it 
separately or inherited it from a common ancestor, I don't give a crap. The 
consumption of milk in northern Europe is just particularly high that's 
all, I've written, you can easily check this fact if you want. I don't try 
to change your or anyone's eating behaviour, I've just given advice 
occasionally to people(mostly friends), that's all I intended to say(by the 
choice of words "preaching" if you're clinging particularly to this). In 
fact I don't give half a shit about you, because I don't know you. For all 
I care, you can drink a liter of milk and jump off a cliff.
By the way, check your facts on lactose digestion by the adults digestive 
system, because roughly 80% of the adult world population loses the ability 
to *completely* digest lactose. This means that there are many people on 
this world, who tolerate certain amounts of lactose in dairy products, 
though whose organisms can't fully convert the lactose, so there is a 
reminder(!) of this undigested chemical, which probably poses a danger to 
their organisms. And the gas which some lactose intolerant friends have 
produced totally proves, there is a threat to their health. You just don't 
see/smell such a flagrant evidence by the majority of people, whose 
digestive systems just partially tolerate it.

Do not feel obliged to reply, because I don't really want to argue for the 
sake of argument(I strongly feel that is your only intention)! Have a nice 
whatever daytime it is now there, where you are!
comments.author: Vanko

comments.text:
*sigh* And there are several countries which are very low in milk 
consumption on the low end of the lifespan spectrum.  There could be any 
number of factors contributing to the lifespan.  Perhaps it's because they 
also don't eat a lot of saturated fats.  Perhaps it's because they eat lots 
of rice.  You don't know.  Conflating correlation with causation is a 
common logical fallacy and is generally symptomatic of wishful thinking.  
There is absolutely no definitive evidence to demonstrate that milk 
consumption shortens lifespan.  None.  It's one of the vegan/vegetarian 
fallacies, along with the idea that milk is terribly acidic, etc., etc.  
Have the lifestyle that you want, but don't try to frighten others into it 
using fearful lies.  That's contemptible, and it's one of the reasons that 
I detest fundamentalists of any stripe - religious, political, or dietary, 
because it's one of their primary approaches.  "Milk shortens your 
lifespan" is right up there with "weapons of mass destruction" or "You are 
hell bound unless you believe as I do" in terms of the Big Lie that so many 
people use to push their viewpoints.  Just because you like the smell of 
your bullshit doesn't mean it's not still bullshit.

Some populations evolved the ability to digest lactose into adulthood, and 
northern Europe is far from the only example.  One of the traditional 
staples of Maasai diet (southern Kenya) is a mix of blood and milk.  There 
are many other examples, and it is accurate to state that the ability to 
digest lactose into adulthood is a part of normal human genetic variation - 
as natural as blonde hair, epicanthic folds in the eyelids, etc.  
Suggesting otherwise is dishonest.
comments.author: SRO 102078

comments.text:
+SRO 102078 I'm not lactose intolerant, I can eat tons of any kind of 
cheese without a problem and drink milk in moderate quantity, although it 
tastes awful. Lactose intolerance is something natural in adults, in the 
class Mammalia, only humans try to digest milk in their adulthood, as a 
consequence some regional populations have developed a certain tolerance 
towards lactose.
 Japan, Hong Kong and Singapore are in the top three of the life expectancy 
list and the consumption of milk in those countries and regions is 
extremely low(in Japan under 100g a day whooops, number one country in the 
world by centenarians, double whooops) in comparison to northern Europe and 
the Western world overall.
comments.author: Vanko

comments.text:
Milk only gives you flatulence and diarrhea if you're lactose intolerant.  
It's never given me either of those things in my life.  As for life 
expectancy by country: United States #34, China #65, as per WHO 2014 data.  
Whoops.  Also: the top 10 countries in milk consumption per capita average 
have an average life expectancy of 78.6 years, while the bottom 10 
countries in milk consumption have an average life expectancy of 74.7 years 
(milk consumption data from U.N. FAO, life expectancy numbers from WHO 
2014).  Drink milk and live longer! :-)

captions.text:
This episode of DNews is brought to you by
Audible.

Milk does a body, something something. But
even if you GOT it, do you WANT it?

Television has run commercials asking if we
have milk and if we are drinking milk for

our strong bones, but science is starting
to look at this and say, "hold up." A study

from Uppsala University in Sweden looked at
how the amount of milk consumed can affect

health in the long term, and according to
their results, mo milk, mo problems.

Their study, which followed over 100,000 men
and women aged 39 to 79 years. The women were

followed for 20 years, and then men for 11,
on average. Overall, their results found that

people who drank three or more glasses of
milk per day died at almost TWICE the rate

of those who drank less than one. So… that's
huge. The study, published in BMJ, says the

reason for the increase in death MAY be because
galactose // which SOUNDS like an awesome

bad guy from a 90s comic book, but it's not,
it's a simple sugar found in milk. They picked

that sugar because of a separate study, where
galactose was given to animals and they died
faster thanks to oxidative stress and inflammation.

Basically, according to their findings, the
risk of death rose 15 percent for every glass

of milk consumed per day, and for women it
actually INCREASED bone fractures, not decreased.

BEFORE YOU FREAK OUT AND DUMP YOUR DAIRY.
Cheese and yogurt and stuff might be okay.

They have little or no galactose. Their study
also found women who ate fermented cheese
products were LESS likely to die.

All this aside, the researchers ended their
study by saying one of my favorite phrases:

MORE RESEARCH IS NEEDED. I quote, "People
should not change their dietary habits because
of this study." It's correlation, not causation.

This got me thinking, why do we even drink
moo juice in the first place? We're not the

ONLY species on the planet to drink another
species milk. There are nursing baby animals

that drink milk from adopted lactating parents,
but the thing is… they're all babies. Most

animals stop drinking milk and lose the ability
to digest it as they age. However, another

study, also from Uppsala University // the
Swedes drink a lot of milk, I guess // reports

ancient Iberian DNA might indicate why we
drink milk at all! The enzyme that allows

us to drink milk, lactase, only evolved in
the last 10,000 years, a blink of an eye in
biological time.

The reason it evolved is because of disaster
-- a famine. It was either, adapt or die,

and somehow the human body was able to form
lactase persistence -- or the ability to digest

lactose as an adult. The drinking of milk
would have allowed humans to gather vitamin

D and absorb calcium, keeping them alive and
healthy -- similar to the newer study, they

also say cheese and yogurt are better, mostly
because they're easier to consume due to lower
levels of lactose due to fermentation.

Bottom line, maybe think about cutting down
on milk servings and substitute it for some

yogurt or cheese instead. too much dairy can
cause health risks like weight gain, diabetes,

cancer and osteoporosis. It can also cause
acne, digestive distress, allergies, asthma

and more! Dairy is controversial, simply because
so many of us love it, but also because it's

popular consumption in the US is driven by
lobbyists.

You have to make your own decisions, so read
the science and let us know what you think!

If you're interested in learning more about
the food you'er shoving in your mouth, Audible.com

massive library of downloadable digital audiobooks.
They've got 150,000 titles and they work on

ANY device. There are fiction books, non-fiction
books, bestsellers, and tons of other categories.

If you like food and haven't read Michael
Pollan, check out In Defense of Food, you'll

never eat the same way again. Super interesting
stuff. You can get any audiobook for free

by going to audible.com/dnews and you'll also
get a 30 day free trial!
